title: scientists 40 mutations coronavirus traced english football match
story: The mutations were discovered by analysing swabs of Covid- patients in Iceland - where almost  cases have been reported so far.It comes as the number of those infected with coronavirus across the world continues to rise - with cases in  countries.In the UK the death toll hit  today, with , people infected.And in the daily Government press conference, Health Secretary Matt Hancock called for , Brits to sign up as volunteers to help the .million people self-isolating for the next  weeks.The new findings - which have not yet been published, meaning they have yet to be scrutinised by other experts - show cases in Iceland could be traced back to three countries, England, Austria and Italy.But, one stand out discovery, was the fact seven infected people all went to the same, undisclosed football match in England.It comes as:The team of Icelandic scientists used genetic sequencing to identy how many mutations the virus had undergone.These genetic iations are like viral fingerprints - and help boffins pinpoint where in the world a virus originated.All viruses undergo mutations as they evolve, which may or may not cause them to behave in dferent ways.Some mutations will make a virus more infectious, others more deadly.Mutating is the process that would have allowed this new strain of coronavirus to attack the human body in the first place - allowing it to pass from its animal host.Scientists believe the new coronavirus remained hidden in animals for years, perhaps even decade before jumping from bats to humans, via a possible but unknown animal, in the Chinese city of Wuhan.Icelandic scientists investigated the virus within their own country, where one death has been reported.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.The health authorities there, along with genetics firm DeCode Genetics, tested , people for coronavirus, according to Information.This included anyone who had been diagnosed, as well as people with symptoms or those in high risk groups for Covid-.Some , volunteers who did not have any symptoms joined the study –  of whom actually tested positive.Complete genome sequencing was carried out and this unveiled clues about how the bug has evolved and the chain of transmission.Kári Stefánsson, director of DeCode Genetics, said: We can see how viruses mutate.We have found  island-specic virus mutations.We found someone who had a mixture of viruses.They had viruses from before and after the mutation, and the only infections traceable to that person are the mutated virus.One person was found to carry two iants of the coronavirus.DeCode Genetics was able to trace how the virus entered Iceland, an island nation home to around , people.Dr Stefánsson added: Some came from Austria. There is another type from people who were infected in Italy.And there is a third type of virus found in people infected in England.Seven people had attended a football match in England.Tap to see where Covid- is near youThe study has not yet been published, meaning it hasnt yet been analysed by other scientists.Dr Derek Gatherer, an infectious disease specialist at Lancaster University, revealed he was not surprised with the findings.He told the MailOnline: This is much as we would expect. All viruses accumulate mutations, but few of them are of much medical consequence.They are valuable in tracing the origins of infection chains.It looks like Iceland has imported quite a few infections from other European countries.Allan Randrup Thomsen, a virologist from the Department of Immunology and Microbiology at the University of Copenhagen, said the results described by the team make good sense.Professor Thomsen said: Coronavirus is known as a virus that can mutate reasonably violently.We have seen reports of iants from China already. That way, it fits well with what one expects.Earlier this month, researchers in China said they had found two main types of coronavirus could be causing infections.The preliminary study found that when the virus first crossed into humans, the ancestral strain - which they named S - subsequently evolved into another version, called L.In their study, they found that the older strain is the more aggressive and faster-spreading of the two.Initially the newer strain, L, was more prevalent - but is now reducing and S has gone onto become more common.The authors suggest that this could be because the disease it causes is less severe, meaning people can carry it for longer before they are hospitalised - making it the risk of passing it on greater.They also claim that the more aggressive version associated with the disease outbreak in Wuhan accounted for about  per cent of analysed strains.But experts warn that the study is very early data and more research is needed.Similar to the flu, Covid- may be more able to spread and infect more people as it becomes well adapted.However, the iants that cause people to get really sick may die out.Dr Gatherer said this process may take a couple of years.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. PRESIDENT Donald Trump said that he wants the country open by Easter - on the same day that the coronavirus US death toll topped , including the first child.The president also warned that economic shutdown could cause suicide by the thousands.Speaking at a virtual town hall meeting today, Trump said: You are going to lose a number of people to the flu. But you are going to lose more people by putting a country into a massive recession or depression.Youre going to lose people. You are going to have suicides by the thousands...Youre going to have instability.Later in the interview, the president reinstated: Depression causes death and a lot of problems.Speaking about opening the country up again, Trump said: I would love to have it opened by Easter.When askedit would be possible to reopen the country on Easter Sunday, April , the president replied: I think its possible. Why isnt it Later, Trump added: Easter is a very special day for me, and I see it sort of in that timeline that Im thinking about.“Wouldn’t it be great to have all of the churches full  …Easter Sunday and you’ll have packed churches all over our country.”Trump said that people can practice good hygiene and social distancing even when they go back to work.The news comes on the same day that the US death toll surpasses , including the countrys first child death.LA County health officials wrote in a press release on Tuesday that the Lancaster boy was one of three new deaths.The officials said: One of the iniduals was a youth under the age of .A Lancaster local wrote on Facebook: I dont have his medical history. We know that the Covid  was discovered after he died.The US Sun can report that the young boy had an underlying heart condition that contributed to his death.Dr Barbara Ferrer, Los Angeles County Public Health Director, said: Each loss we experience in LA County is tragic, and we are sending our heartfelt condolences to the families and loved ones whove had to endure this tragedy.While Public Health is doing everything possible to mitigate the impact of this disease in our community, we can only flatten the curveEVERYONE takes social distancing seriously and adheres to all isolation and quarantine orders issued by our Health Officer.”Health experts have also warned that millions could diethe lockdown is lted too early.Tom Inglesby, of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, made the comments on Monday after the president said he would reconsider Americas social distancing rules amid the COVID- outbreak.Despite the Presidents instinct to protect the US economy, Inglesby wrote: COVID would spread widely, rapidly, terribly, could kill potentially millions in the year ahead with huge social and economic impact across the country.At a Coronavirus Task Force Briefing on Monday, Trump stated: Our country was not built to be shut down.We are going to be opening up our country for business because our country was meant to be open.We are going to get it all going again very soon.Trumps projected time frame to get the country back up and running, is a lot sooner than three or four months.He added that officials wont let the cure be worse than the problem.The president could not give a specic date on when the lockdowns would end, but said health officials would be using data to give a recommendation on when that may happen.At the end of the -day period, well make a decision as to which way we want to go. Where we want to go. The timing, Trump said.The  day period refers to the new guidelines Trump issued on March , aimed at slowing the spread of COVID-, which means the President could lt restrictions at the end of the month. The  day period refers to the new guidelines Trump issued on March , aimed at slowing the spread of COVID-, which means the President could lt restrictions at the end of the month.There are currently over , of COVID- cases in America.The coronavirus death toll currently stands at  in the United States but is expected to rise, Dr Jermone Adams warned on Monday.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: italy coronavirus cases rise again
story: ITALYS coronavirus death toll has soared by  in a single day to , - just as the country hoped it had turned the corner.The total number of confirmed cases in the virus-ravaged Mediterranean country has now risen to , from a previous figure of ,.Yesterday, data revealed a drop in the rate of deaths and new infections with the number of deaths rising by  - the smallest increase for four days.Italys Civil Protection Agency showed , new cases on Monday, nearly  fewer than the day-to-day increase of , new cases reported from a day earlier.The number of deaths followed a similar trend with  virus-related deaths registered on Monday compared to  on Sunday and  on Saturday.It was hoped the day-to-day figures for new cases and deaths going down was an indication the national lockdown is working.Since February, Italy had been following an exponential growth curve with cases and deaths roughly doubling every three days.It has now seen more fatalities than any other country on the planet.But the man in charge of collecting the data fears the actual figures could be ten times higher as testing for the disease has often been limited to people seeking hospital care.A ratio of one certied case out of every  is credible, Angelo Borrelli, the head of the Civil Protection Agency, told La Repubblica newspaper.After four weeks of steep increases in deaths and cases, the growth rate has eased since Sunday, raising hopes that the most aggressive phase of the contagion might be over.The official numbers of the last two days indicate a slowdown in the epidemic, said Giorgio Gori, title: how brits are coping with staying in
story: YESTERDAY was the day Britain woke up in lockdown.A nation that cherishes its personal freedoms must now get used to another way of le. Loved ones went unkissed, children missed school while many grafters suddenly found themselves at a loss for things to do.But at the same time, those keeping Britain afloat — NHS heroes, supermarket workers, delivery drivers, first responders and others — stoically went about their business.Social distancing and self isolation are now part of the fabric of our lives.It is a time of anxiety and uncertainty, yet Brits are responding with courage and resilience.Here we speak to six about how they are coping.MUM Joanne Robinson yesterday welcomed Prime ­Minister Boris Jonhnson’s lockdown as she is “petried” of catching coronavirus.The former chip shop worker, , said she has been in tears over fears she will die from the disease as she has an underlying health problem.  She lives with her son Wesley, , at the family home in Eccles, Greater Manchester.Joanne, who is on disability benefit, said: “I am happy that Boris has gone with the lockdown. It’s a good thing to do as people do need telling.“I’m terried of catching it — I’ve been a bit tearful over itI’m honest.“I’m petried as I’ve had health problems — I used to smoke and I was poorly with pneumonia after Christmas.“People shouldn’t be going out and mixing and spreading the disease. We really don’t want too many people falling sick and the NHS being overwhelmed. I have seen the pictures on the TV of Italy and it looks terrying there.“I am watching the news on the telly a lot as I want to see what’s going on. ButI feel a bit down I just watch the music channels instead.“I do feel a bit isolated as I’ve been staying home for the last few days as I don’t want to mix with too many people.“It’s a scary time and it feels very odd not being able to go out and see other people.“I do miss my friends and don’t really like self-isolating too much. I’m running out of milk so I think I’ll send Wesley down the shops.“ButI have to go out, I have a face mask which I’ll use, I’ll have to go to the cash point to get some money and then head to the supermarket.“People do need to stop panic buying as there is enough for everyone.CORONAVIRUS has stopped Tyrique Smith, , from seeing his girlfriend of three years.Tyrique said: “It’s so frustrating not being able to see my girlfriend as we usually spend a lot of time together.   “I can’t go to the gym anymore, I can’t go to social events to visit my family and friends. I can only go to Tesco or go out for a jog.“Currently all I do is read books and watch Netflix.“My daily routine has been ruined because I normally spend most of my day outside. It’s a big change.”Tyrique’s job takes him around central London but lockdown orders mean he now spends most of his time at home.And Tyrique said stockpilers have meant he can’t buy the foods he normally enjoys.He added: “It’s also hard to carry on with my normal lestyle generally. It’s all very frustrating.”JESSICA Jones, , is stuck at home with children Florence, , and Alfred, .She said: “I am embracing being at home, doing the sewing, DIY and gardening we never seem to have time to do.  “The family are developing our routines, exercising, doing school work online and trying not to get under each other’s feet. I’m checking elderly neighbours have what they need.“But I really feel for the children, who will be missing out on seeing friends at a time in their lives they’ll never get back again.“They were supposed to be doing organised walks on Exmoor and Dartmoor and love the Scouts and bell-ringing at the church. That’s all cancelled of course.“Our village, Bampton, is quiet and where people seem to be on the whole keeping calm and carrying on. People are being respectful and kind.They’re volunteering their time to help their neighbours, the shops and anyone in need.“However, a lot of second homers seem to have arrived which has upset locals because they’re buying up stuff from the shops.”JANE Cohen, , is self-isolating at home with her -year-old daughter Grace but it means she has not been able make daily visits to check on her elderly parents.Magazine writer Jane said: “It’s day five of self-isolation and my sanity is being hacked away one nerve at a time.  “Working from home doesn’t best please my daughter, who is continually rolling her eyes at me as I sit in the living room with a mound of paperwork.“Of course we love each other but this forced togetherness is driving us nuts.“I usually see my elderly parents every day but now it’s a visit to drop off shopping and their impressive bulky prescription delivery at the bottom of the garden.“I am worried about them and beg them not to go out because of their health vulnerabilities. I think they, too, are slowly going insane with the confinement.“I realise how important it is to stay home but God, it’s draining.“For now it’s only the beginning of this hell. I believe it is going to get a whole lot worse before it gets better. I have no idea how I’ll get through the next three weeks or so.” KEVIN Mallett, , had customers calling late on Monday to cancel jobs after Boris Johnson’s announcement plunged us into lockdown.He said: “At pm last night my phone was going berserk with cancellations.  “People are not saying they don’t want the work done, but that they want to wait until coronavirus is over and it is safe to mix with people again.“I have a bathroom job I have to finish but after that there will be nothing.“If I didn’t have savings, I would be screwed. If I get through this with any of my savings intact I’ll be happy.“But I am not letting this spoil my le. What can you do  It is no one’s fault.”He added: “Most of my family work for the NHS. My mum and my sisters do.“They have got no choice, they are going to work regardless.“Most of my friends are self- employed. One says regardless of how bad it gets he will try to work because he has no money. He’s desperate.“My house deposit is going to be spent on my food shop and my bills. No one knows how long this will go on for. No one knows the time scale.”SELF-employed bricklayer Yusuf Abbott was the first on his site to stop going to work.Yusuf, , said: “I have decided to stop working even though my colleagues haven’t. I think it’s only a matter of time before the sites close.  “The others don’t want to stop yet. They are hoping for Boris Johnson to close the sites and it’s what I’m hoping for as well.“I would workI knew the people I was working with were keeping their distance and washing their hands but at the moment there is no hand sanitiser on site and the canteen is quite crowded.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Yusuf, who lives in rented accommodation in Birmingham with his we, also said he is worried about his elderly mum and his neighbours.He said: “I don’t want the country to have to worry about the infection spreading even further and I can help by not leaving the house as much as possible. After only a couple of days in self-isolation I am spending a lot of time on the internet.”Yusuf now only goes out for essential groceries and to exercise — and urges everyone  to do the same. He said: “Just stay at home and limit your exposure to others.”  GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: writer covid 19 coronavirus diary
story: Here, she shares the diary of her symptoms:It all starts with a cough. For days everyone has been making virus jokes every time anyone so much as clears their throat, so I am not particularly worried.The cough is so mild it is almost insignicant — coming and going every  minutes or so. Under any normal circumstances, I would ignore it completely. But these are not normal circumstances.With no other symptoms, I start to wondermy cough is born entirely out of corona-paranoia.I don’t have a fever but the government advice is clear and I know I will have to stay inside for seven days. I cross my fingers it will be gone by the morning.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.The cough is still here. Now it’s impossible to deny it is both new and continuous. It is a soundtrack that follows me around the flat, where I am working from home.By the afternoon, things have got worse. My whole head is aching and I alternate between shivering with cold and feeling so hot I have to shed multiple layers.I try to carry on as normal. By the end of my sht, I admit defeat and go straight to bed at pm. My jaw, my forehead, every muscle in my shoulders is aching and I can’t seem to stop myself shaking.After a bad night’s sleep, I wake to find I feel, bizarrely . . . fine  My headache has cleared, and while the cough is still there I feel about as well as I did on Tuesday.I feel smug that my immune system seems to have fought it off so quickly. I check in with my mates.Five of us had a final night out on Saturday, two days before the Government advised people to avoid pubs and restaurants.It seems the announcement did not come soon enough. Three are now suffering the same symptoms as me.One pal texts that his cough has gone chesty, another that he feels like his head is stuffed with cotton wool.This virus is a real rollercoaster — and today it s with a vengeance.I’m still coughing away, but worse than that is the feeling of dizziness and total exhaustion.I sit at my computer for an hour attempting to work before I give up and go straight to bed, where I remain prone for the next seven hours.I feel completely deathly at this point. I’m feverish, my head feels like it is filled with pins and needles and every inch of my body aches.I have absolutely zero energy — even going to the bathroom seems to take a superhuman amount of strength. Worst of all, there’s nothing I can take to relieve the pain.We’re out of paracetamol and as my boyfriend has to self-isolate due to my symptoms, there’s no chance of him running out to get some. It sounds like the shops are totally out of it anyway.By the evening, I feel just well enough to sit up in bed and FaceTime my mum.She immediately puts her entire supply of paracetamol in the post, and asks my sister to do the same. The drugs drop can’t come soon enough.My temperature feels more normal. I still feel pretty weak and pathetic, and commute from the bed to the sofa for a busy day of watching telly and playing Bananagrams with my boyfriend.With our food supplies running low, our neighbours have kindly agreed to pick up some essentials. We ask for milk, bread and eggs.An hour later, and there’s a bottle of milk left outside our door — but they text to say they went to multiple shops and bread and eggs are sold out everywhere.By the evening, I’m starting to feel more like myself. We dial in for a Zoom video chat session with our mates.It’s not quite the same as a night at the pub — especially as three of us contribute mainly coughing.I’ve stopped coughing! In fact, I feel pretty much back to normal, although my chest still feels a little tight.I’ve also lost my appetite — highly unusual for me — but that is probably because I haven’t left the flat or done any kind of exercise for the best part of a week.My boyfriend has also managed to avoid getting symptoms. We’ve kept our distance but, living in close quarters, I suspect he may have caught the virus and been lucky enough not to get ill.I feel endlessly grateful that I’ve had such a mild strain — as most young, healthy people are likely to get. Obviously, many people are not so lucky.I read a terrying stat that every person who contracts coronavirus is likely to pass it on to three people — and once that process has been repeated ten times, , people are infected.The message is clear: stay at home.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dr hilary coronavirus questions
story: AS the nation enters its second day of lockdown, many people have been left ­confused about going into quarantine and caring for their loved ones.  We have been inundated with your questions for our resident doctor, Dr Hilary Jones — with hundreds flooding in overnight.If you have a question, go to thesun drhilary or use the form below to ask yours. Today, Britain’s most respected doctor answers questions about what you should and shouldn’t do ­during the lockdown to safeguard your health…Q: I’M separated from my partner. We have children together and they split their time between both our homes. Is it safe for our children to still move between homes A: IT is important that children can see both their parents but, of course, the more travelling they do then the more dferent contacts they have and the greater the risk of transmission. So it still needs to be kept to a minimum.Q: I SUFFER from mild asthma but have not had an attack for many years. Should I be self-isolating A: PEOPLE with asthma may be at higher risk of getting very sick from coronavirus and are therefore in the at-risk group. But there are iable degrees of asthma.Some people may have had an attack three years ago and nothing since and some people’s asthma is well controlled with medication so they are not really vulnerable.If in your case getting a cold or cough usually triggers an asthma attack then you are vulnerable.It is important you practise social distance, avoid having ­visitors and work from home where possible.Q: I’M over , but am fit and healthy. Owing to my age, I have been told to self-isolate but I am unable to get an online shopping delivery. Is it safe for me to still go out A: IF you cannot get a relative, friend or neighbour to shop for you then you can go out to get essential shopping.But as you are in the at-risk group make sure you don’t come within two metres of other people, ensure your trip is kept as short as possible and stock up on items to last you seven to ten days.Q: MY we is in the high-risk group, meaning people at a higher risk of severe illnessthey contract coronavirus. Does she need to self-isolate from me and can I still go out to do our shopping A: SHE doesn’t need to self-isolate from you but be extra cautious. You can still go out to do your essential shopping and collect medication as well as taking your daily exercise.Remember to take all the necessary ­precautions, such as keeping a two metre distance from other people and thoroughly washing your hands as soon as youhome so you reduce the risk of bringing the virus home to the person at risk.Q: I HAVE had an online grocery delivery. Should I be worried about the virus being on the packaging and should I wash fresh produce like fruit A: WHEN any packages arrive take the contents out, throw away the packages and wash your hands.Coronavirus does not live within food, but it makes sense to wash fresh fruit and veg under the tap, peel fruit before eating it and cook vegetables as you would normally do, as cooking would kill the virus easily.Wash your hands again after preparing food.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Q: MY sister is due to have a final fitting of dentures at the dentist. Is it OK for her to go A: DENTISTS have now been given clear guidance in cancelling all dental treatments unless they are emergencies.This is because any close contact with people’s mouths and throats and even their breathing would be high-risk exposure to any virus present.Q I LIVE with my nan who is  and my mum who is . I work in a primary school and my mum works in a hospital. I am worried we are both going out to work and we are going to bring the virus home. Should we still be working while living with my nan A: YOUR nan’s age puts her in the at-risk group and she has to be careful about contact with others.This, however, does not include you and your mum as you live in the same household and currently have no symptoms.You should, however, physically distance yourself from your Nan, who should have no other visitors.If you or your mum did develop symptoms you would need to self-isolate well away from your Nan or see whether other ­members of the family could take her in temporarily.Q: MY daughter believes she may have had this virus about three weeks ago but isn’t sure. Is there a test she should be taking to seeshe has had this virus and is now well A: A TEST to find out whether somebody has had the virus, has recovered and is therefore now immune will be a game-changer. Such a test exists and will become available in the future to many more people.However, it is essential that healthcare professionals are tested first so we can discover whether they are immune and can therefore come back to working with patients safely.It will take time to produce enough tests for everyone.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus virus lockdown leaving home transport questions
story: BRITAIN was plunged into chaos and confusion over what they could and couldnt do after the coronavirus lockdown.The Government was accused of muddying the waters for the lockdown rules - as people up and down the country lined up and demanded answers.No insisted that their advice was very clear and people should read it in full to find out what they should do.But already police were warning that the new rules were so extensive that they wouldnt be able to enforce it.Downing Street said yesterday that fines of £ were on the cards for Brits flouting the rules - and that could go upneeded.Here, The Sun presents an easy to digest guide of all the key questions so you can keep you and your loved ones safe.In a dramatic address to the nation on Monday evening, the PM said that Brits should NOT be going outside their homes unless it was for one of four reasons - and they should not be meeting up with anyone  unless they are already living with you.That is for food or essentials, a medical appointment, to go to workyou have to, and for exercise once a day.Tens of thousands of non-essential shops were ordered to close last night.But banks, post offices and garages were set to remain open - leading to confusion as to whether Brits were allowed to visit these or not.Communal play and exercise areas inside parks will also be shut down, but not parks themselves.Mums and dads can take their kids out with themits not safe to leave them alone.All gatherings of more than two people in public are forbidden – meaning a ban on all social events, including weddings and baptisms.But the advice did not specy whether it would be allowed to meet one person - providing they were a safe two metre distance apart.The PM said: You should not be meeting friends. If your friends ask you to meet, you should say no.You should not be meeting family members who do not live in your home.No still couldnt confirm whether one person could meet another one person.Downing Street stressed that no one should be leaving their homes unless they had to anyway.Experts told lovers today thatthey wanted to see each other during the lockdown they should move in with each other - and stay there.Brits wont be allowed in and out of each others homes as they would risk spreading the virus.It is unclear whether partners would be able to see each otherthey stayed two metres apart, as is the guidance for everyone at the moment unless you share a home.No were today asked specically whether the lockdown would mean that boyfriends and girlfriends should not see each other.Downing Street stressed that the rules were clear and that people should only be going out of the house alone, with members of their own live-in family - orit were for work reasons.The PMs spokesperson said: I think the rules are clear in relation to when you are out of the house, only do so with members of your own household orits for work reasons.Boris said everyone who could work from home should be doing so.But there was confusion about exactly which businesses would be shutting and which would stay open.Sadiq Khan said construction workers in the capital should NOT go into work, but Michael Gove said earlier they could as long as they stayed a safe distance apart.No has said anyone who can work at home must do so, and avoid public transport. This includes all workers in an office based situation.If they absolutely have to go in to do their job, they are allowed to do so, but must stay at least two metres apart from other colleagues.This will include people working in factories, for example, who cant work from home.Work meetings are allowed, even though they break the gatherings rule.Again, people must stay a safe distance apart.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.     Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits must keep working
story: BRITS were yesterday urged by the Health Secretary to keep working to save the country from economic disaster.As many of the nation’s million workers as possible should carry on from home, they were told. But those who cannot must keep commuting — as long as bosses keep them safe, Matt Hancock said.No  insisted that as well as frontline NHS staff, key workers included Britain’s army of construction employees and manufacturing staff.But there was initial confusion over the “rushed advice”.London Tube trains were crammed with rush-hour commuters yesterday.That sparked a row between the Government and London Mayor Sadiq Khan over who was to blame for the chaos.Mr Hancock said: “I want to be clear that where people absolutely cannot work from home, they can still go to work — indeed it is important they do to keep the country running.”And he lashed out at Mr Khan for failing to run enough Tube trains in London after services were cut during the outbreak.Government sources said while Transport for London staffing was down  per cent, as many as  per cent of the Tubes had stopped.Mr Hancock insisted: “There is no good reason in the information that I’ve seen that the current ­levels of Tube provision should be as low as they are.”But Mr Khan said, for safety reasons, it was “simply not true” he was able to run more. He also said the PM slapped him down during a meeting on whether builders should go to work.Mr Hancock put the onus on bosses to keep their workers safe, saying: “In work, in many, many instances, the two-metre rule can be applied. Employers have a duty to ensure workers are two metres apart.”It came as Sports Direct owner Mike Ashley tried to keep stores open — then pushed up prices. His group told staff its fitness ranges made it a vital asset.But it later announced that its shops would close.Ashley’s stores had hiked prices by more than  per cent on some goods. Sports Direct blamed lack of clarity for the shops fiasco, and supply problems for the rises.Meanwhile, Wetherspoons boss Tim Martin told staff to “go work at Tesco” instead as the pub firm warned they could face delays over pay.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctors nurses support army of volunteers
story: NOT since World War Two has our country needed us more.The NHS is doing heroic work battling Covid-. But as the disease relentlessly spreads and deaths soar, it will not cope without a monumental national effort of a kind not seen for  years.The exhausted doctors and nurses on the frontline, dealing with stricken or recovering patients, now need the support of an army of , volunteers. If you are in good health and unable to work, why not join them It has been moving beyond measure to witness the , retired or former medics, nurses and pharmacists rejoining the NHS to fight this disease.They could be safe at home. Instead they have put themselves in harm’s way. That takes great courage and public spirit. MPs may not be popular these days, but those workers include Tory Maria Caulfield and Labour’s Dr Rosena Allin-Khan. We salute both.And we wish luck to the , final-year doctors and , student nurses who, at the very start of their careers, are tasked with tackling the gravest public health crisis in a century.They and all their colleagues should know, from the thousands of “I Love NHS” messages pouring into us from Sun readers, how grateful the nation is.Millions are doing their bit just by staying home. Many are going the extra mile to help friends, neighbours and OAPs who are self-isolating. Some, with their own jobs in peril, have poured money into good causes close to ruin.For their part, some of our businesses are repurposing factories to produce ventilators and other vital supplies.Now, the Government is asking every one of us to volunteer for the NHSwe can. Together we can help the health service beat this virus and restore some semblance of normality while minimising casualties. And it is desperately urgent.As the latest heartbreaking death toll shows, this crisis is likely to get much worse before it gets better. THE eerie, deserted streets tell their own story. Britain has begun to listen and obey.More than  million of us watched Boris Johnson’s stark, historic address to the nation — among the highest TV audience figures ever. And it hit home.Yes, there were still some crammed carriages on London’s depleted Tube yesterday. There is still confusion over some of the guidance and rules — and more clarity would be welcome.But there WILL be mistakes and inconsistencies from the Government. It is having to react minute by minute to a sudden, global catastrophe. It cannot cover off every inidual situation. We all have to use our common sense too.The vast majority of people get that. They back the PM and the lockdown and are grimly but calmly sticking by it.We are reacting with fortitude. Let’s keep that going.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus a level students jane moore
story: REMEMBER that moment when you finished your final exam and walked out of the gymnasium door in to a glorious few weeks of freedom and celebration Those born in  lucked out with the Summer of ’, with its sweltering hot days and signature whf of melting tarmac, while the rest of us made do with the usual unpredictable British weather.But we didn’t care. We were high on euphoria and expectation before the inevitable responsibilities and occasional disappointments of adult le set in.For me, it meant a week in Tywyn, Wales, in the caravan of my friend Mandy’s mum and dad, followed by a summer job in Littlewoods and Sundays spent hanging around the local rec with my mates while passing round a warm, spittle-filled bottle of budget cider.Ah, those were the days. Today’s kids are more likely to be drinking canned Pinot Grigio at an American-style prom party before heading off on a family holiday to Spain, but the sense of closure they feel at the end of exams is exactly the same. It’s a rite of passage.So for all those GCSE and A-level students for whom Covid- has put paid to that “end of exams” feeling, I have nothing but the utmost sympathy.Last Wednesday I was on a dog walk with my youngestwhen news came in that her GCSEs were off.It’s tempting to think that she and the rest of Class  might have whooped with joy at this unprecedented cancellation of national exams, but that would be to sorely underestimate the level of pressure placed on their generation to get a qualication that will elevate them out of the in-tray of le and into paid employment.Like the Olympic athletes who’ve spent the past few years training for that one event in Tokyo that has been postponed until next year, our kids have been preparing for exams that their parents and teachers have drummed into them are so critically important to their future.So forgive them , despite the deaths that give perspective to the little things that many of us find frustrating about this plague on all our houses, they allow themselves a spell of feeling deeply sorry for themselves.They will now be given “predicted” grades — though the Government is still frustratingly vague on the exact detail of how they will be decided upon.There has been some suggestion that mock results might be a factor but, let’s face it, they’re rarely taken seriously at the time and never match the grades kids get in the real thing. So let’s hope they come up with something fairer.Either way, it’s going to be potentially fraught with pitfalls.“I wanted to earn my grades,” the youngest said, plaintively, the other day. “Now I feel like all my hard work has been for nothing.”I reassured her that, one day, knowledge such as “changes to Tanzania’s economy through private and foreign investment” , “the formation of polyesters through the reaction between dicarboxylic acid monomers and diol monomers”and “parallel and collinear vectors”might come in handy when, ten years from now, she’s at a pub quiz. Or maybe not.Which brings me to my final point on this unprecedented cancellation of GCSEs and A-levels.The latter are fine as they are, but perhaps those in the upper echelons of education could use this time of isolation to take a long, hard look at GCSEs and whether they are fit for purpose in the modern world Most kids know their subject strengths and weaknesses by the time they’re  so, aside from basic maths and English, which prove useful whatever your chosen employment, do they really need their heads crammed with often obscure information that,needed in later le, they could simply look up on Google Better, surely, to teach them vital le skills such as entrepreneurialism, money management, how to compose an impressive CV and do well in job interviews Like a reverse version of a minute’s silence, it’s to show our hard-working NHS staff how much we appreciate their efforts at this deeply challenging time.So whether you do it in a garden balcony windowbox or post it live on social media, put your hands together and show that we care about them too.MADONNA has posted an, er, inspirational Instagram video of herself ponticating on the Covid- plague while luxuriating in a bath full of rose petals.Her Madgeness declares: “That’s the thing about Covid-. It doesn’t care about how rich you are, how famous you are, how funny you are, how smart you are, where you live, how old you are, what amazing stories you can tell.“It’s the great equaliser and what’s terrible about it is what’s great about it.”Hmmmm. Nice sentiment, but the reality of self-isolation for the majority brings to mind the famous quote from George Orwell’s Animal Farm. “All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others.”Be it the Queen Of Pop, with her vast mansion and multi-million dollar nest egg to see her through these trying times, or The Queen with her “skeleton staff of eight” – being in lockdown is far nicer when you’re wealthy.But when there’s loads of you in a pokey space and with no discernible means of paying next month’s rent, it’s not so “great”. GOVERNMENT advice on who should be doing what and when is still a little woolly.And where there’s potential loopholes there are those who will either misunderstand or willfully exploit them.Step forward Sports Direct boss Mike Ashley who, post-lockdown, told his staff they should turn up for work before being publicly shamed in to telling them to stay home after all.But with cycle shops being allowed to stay open, he could perhaps mitigate that as he’s in the business of sports equipment, he thought the same rule applied to his business too.­Similarly, while the building work on one house near me has ceased, another is still ongoing with at least eight construction workers – all of whom will have either shared a van or taken public transport to get there.So one suspects the Government is going to have to ramp up the “lockdown” rhetoric to make it clearer exactly what is deemed essential and what’s not.Meanwhile, I’m going to exploit this small pocket of vagueness by hopping on my bike and heading to the local pharmacy for a packet of hair dye, not least because it comes with a handy pair of disposable gloves.As the Donald Trump meme shows above, no one wants to see that much harsh reality.THE closure of McDonald’s prompted s of people to queue round the block for one last Big Mac.They shouldn’t worry.Given that a man in Utah claims to own the world’s oldest McDonald’s burgerand it shows no sign of decay.All those desperate McAddicts could have bought  of them and they’d still be edible at Christmas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple marry hours before lockdown
story: THE last couple to tie the knot before the lockdown yesterday revealed: We got wed by the skin of our teeth.Jamie and Natalie Speight, of Leeds, West Yorks, were originally due to get married on April .But IT technician Jamie, , had a feeling it would be cancelled so called his local vicar to rebook.Jamie and Natalie, , got hitched at .pm on Monday - precisely four hours before PM Boris Johnson addressed the nation and shutdown the country.Last night, thrilled Jamie told The Sun: We were originally going to get married with  guests.But I just had a feeling at the back end of last week that it wouldnt happen because of the coronavirus pandemic.We contacted the vicar and asked himwe could bring it forward. The only time slot he had was Monday.I didnt care how many people were there or what day or time. I just wanted to marry Natalie.Only six guests were permitted to attend the ceremony - the bride and grooms parents and two witnesses.After the service at Immaculate Heart of Mary church on Harrogate Road they had a reception at Natalies parents home.Jamie added: The church closed at pm. It was a mad scramble but we did it by the skin of our teeth.We then watched Boris address the nation - and my heart skipped a beat when he said all weddings would now be cancelled.Had we not rebooked the chances are we would not have been getting married until next year.It still felt special because it was our day.We are almost certainly the last couple to get married before the lockdown was announced.The couple, who met in August  and got engaged four months later, planned to honeymoon at Disneyland Paris but cancelled the trip.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bobcat captured savaging farmers chickens
story: The bobcat had gone berserk and was savaging other animals when it was shot by the terried landowner.Pellets from the shotgun blast injured its eye and scared it off.The bobcat’s owner arrived and RSPCA officers were called to try to track the male animal down near Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk.The RSPCA managed to capture the bobcat — a species that can only be kept in the UK with a special licence.Last night it was recovering in a local vets while West Suffolk Council launched an investigation on how it could have got loose.A source told The Sun: “When it was spotted they feared it was a full-size lynx, but after being captured it was clear it was actually a bobcat.It was hit with a shotgun pellet trying to scare it away from attacking the other animals. It’s a miracle it wasn’t worse.”Bobcats are part of the Dangerous Wild Animals Act and people need to get special permission to be allowed to keep one in the UK.They are native to North America and prefer to hunt rabbits and hares, but also go for chickens, geese and other birds.Bobcats usually avoid humans but can become aggressive. Some with rabies having attacked people.Last night the RSPCA said: “The bobcat — an adult male — is licensed to an owner in the area.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: looters food packages coronavirus
story: VULNERABLE folk have had food parcels stolen from their doorsteps.One meals delivery ­service said at least four families had been targeted.A man was seen on a doorbell camera snatching a £ Gousto delivery.The grub was meant for Naseem Walker, , whose daughter Leila, seven, has a chromosome disorder.Naseem, of Wimbledon, South West London, was targeted on Monday.She said: “We are a vulnerable family because of my daughter, it is disgusting someone has done this.“It’s come to something that food has now become such a valuable commodity you have got gangs going round stealing it.”Later that same evening the PM urged people to use more food deliveries.Naseem said Gousto told her they knew of three other similar cases.A spokeswoman said: “We always ensure our customers specy a safe place to leave their recipe box.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lion match feisty lioness
story: The pair, from the same pride in Kenyas Masai Mara, show the male jumping on his hind legs in a futile attempt to get the upper hand - before she knocks him on to his back.Photographer Kevin Rooney documented the scene in the Mara North Conservancy in November.He explains: “Our guide, Johnson from Kicheche Bush Camp, informed us they are all young adults from the same pride.They were just very playful and honing their stalking and pouncing skills on each other after we came across them.“The initial sparring then led to a short bout of boxing, with a couple of decent jabs, crosses and uppercuts.I think it was pretty much a split decision on which of the playful adversaries won the bout, and looking through my images that evening, it made me and my we Karen both grin and realise how special it had been.”The Masai Mara is home to the largest population of big cats in Africa, with more than  in the area.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ba must work contact coronavirus
story: British Airways bosses were accused of putting staff and passengers at risk after ordering the workforce not to self-isolate andto the skies.But BA claimed it was carrying out government advice.One of  cabin crew and three pilots on a Boeing  tested positive for Covid- after flying to Dubai.All of the flying staff were subject to nasal swabs after Flight BA arrived in the emirate on Saturday.The examination - so invasive it left one steward with a nose bleed - is a requirement for all crews arriving in Dubai, although no such test is required for staff arriving in the UK.The test results came back -hours later, after which time the same staff had operated theFlight BA back to Heathrow, arriving later on Saturday.Dubai health officials informed BA of the positive test result, and an airline manager contacted each crew member on the flight with the news.But to widespread amazement the airline instruction to crew was there’s  “no need to self-isolate unless you show any symptoms”.Unite last night told The Sun the entire crew and all passengers on both inbound and outbound services to Dubai should be in isolation.A stunned BA worker told The Sun: “It is the entry requirement in Dubai that crew must be swabbed and this duly happened.“But only when the crew had ed home was it confirmed that a colleague had coronavirus.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.“Incredibly all staff were told no further action is required, unless they showed Covid- symptoms.“The rest of the frontline BA team were told they don’t need to self isolate.“It means we have a live case of coronavirus that BA does not appear concerned about. Passengers and staff are at risk.“The crew were due to work on other flights knowing staff could all be infected, and passing on coronavirus.“Workers should be self-isolating with their families and could be a walking time-bomb.“Staff are fuming that so little is seemingly being done and they’re being treated with such disregard.”BA crew were so incensed by the “lack of action” by bosses they complained to the Unite union, who have taken up the case with airline officials.Crews arriving in foreign airports are forced to be swabbed for coronavirus before being allowed through Customs - but there is no such procedure for air staff arriving in the UK.BA boss Alex Cruz has announced the airline faces a “battle for survival” as he grounded jets and vastly reduced its timetable.Last night BA told The Sun: “We are following medical advice from Public Health England. The safety and welfare of our customers and crew is always our priority.”But a Unite union spokesperson told The Sun: “This is a very serious matter.“The government advice is clearly inadequate and needs revision and conflicts with the advice for iniduals.“It is vital that British Airways ensures that the entire crew immediately self-isolates and are paid in full during this time.The passengers on both the inbound and outbound flight must all be immediately informed about the positive coronavirus test.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits stranded coronavirus beg government
story: THOUSANDS of Brits were still stranded abroad by the global coronavirus lockdown last night - amid growing fury over the “useless” Foreign Office response.Huge numbers of holidaymakers or business travellers were asked toto the UK immediately by the Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab on Monday. But many still had no way of getting home last night after airlines grounded fleets and airports across the world shut down.Trapped travellers yesterday accused the Foreign Office of dragging its feet while other nations sent flights to fetch stranded citizens. A seriously ill mum among hundreds of trapped at a locked-down coronavirus airport in Bali begged last night: “Get me home or I’ll die here.”Pauline Bennett, , and her -year-old husband Steve are among around  fleeing Brits who found outbound flights cancelled yesterday. And the desperate mum-of-two fears she will collapse once her chemotherapy tablets run out tomorrow .Special needs support worker Pauline sobbed last night: “It’s all very well for the Foreign Office to say come home now - but we can’t - we’re marooned. I have a precancerous bone marrow disease which could turn to full-blown leukaemiaI don’t take medication.“But my tablets run out on Thursday and I’ve been told there’s no way of getting home to get more. Without the drugs my blood will thicken and I might not make it.“I’ve had to queue up alongside hundreds of other British people desperate to get home in a place where it’s been impossible to keep a safe distance from the virus. AndI get it I’ll be in big trouble because my immune system is weak. I’m at my wits’ end.”Mum-of-two Pauline and joiner husband Steve from Bishops Stortford, Essex had been enjoying a dream holiday with daughter Olivia, , when corona clamps kicked in. They brought forward theirflight and paid £, each for business class seats to escape - only to find their Emirates flight had been cancelled as transfers via Dubai were halted.Pauline said: “We’ve been told we could stuck here for three months but Foreign Office have been useless - they just send links to their website.“Hundreds of other Brits have been arriving here every hour - people with babies, old folk and families all queuing together at a time when we should be apart. Poland and Israel are sending planes to save their citizens so why can’t Britain ”Vital British key workers were among those crowded at Bali’s chaotic Denpasar Airport yesterday, including NHS staff, a pharmacist, teachers, a prison custody officer, firefighter, a food distribution worker and an army reservist.Mum Demi Gregson, , was left stranded in a packed customer services queue at Bali Airport last night with mum Kelly, , and daughter Amy, eight months. Demi sobbed: Amys prescription milk formula will run out next week but weve been told well be here for months - its a nightmare.We were supposed to be flying to paradise but now were trapped in hell. The disease is probably moving amongst us and British government must rescue us - it’s the only way we’ll get out of here now.”Around  more Brits were trapped on the opposite side of the globe in New Zealand last night after the country went into lock down. Retired geophysicist and grandad-of-four Steve Meadows, , on holiday with -year-old we Pauline said: “We’re trapped and getting more and more anxious about getting home now.“I’m not sure we’ll make it home unless the UK sends a relief flight because commercial routes back are all shut down. We’re in the high risk age group and are having to try to keep our distance from other people while we wait for news. It’s a very worrying time.”Rescue flights to bring back more than  British tourists stranded in Peru will begin this week, the Foreign Office said. The Peruvian government placed the country into lockdown last Monday, with no flights allowed to enter or leave without government permission.Thousands of British Indians were also feared to be trapped in India last night after taking winter breaks in their Punjab Sikh homeland. Reports emerged of them being forcibly locked down by authorities and put under effective house arrest.A Sikh Federation spokesman said: “The Brits are being treated like criminals with the police marking the properties where they are staying with signs to report any Brits that leave these properties. Those there are unable to get flights back to the UK or get to airports. They have contacted MPs and the Foreign Office but have had no answers. They feel abandoned.”Mr Raab vowed to redouble efforts to get Brits home last night by keeping commercial routes open, sending repatriation flights and offering loans in emergencies.He said: “We know that there has been considerable pressure, because of the restrictions being placed by countries around the world and the rate at which it is being done with limited or no notice. We have doubled our capacity, we are now doubling it again to deal with the surge in demand.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: caravan park permanent residents can stay
story: THOUSANDS of caravan and holiday home owners were left in panic yesterday over fears they would be kicked out of their properties amid the coronavirus lockdown.A Government announcement on Monday night said all campsites, caravan parks and tourist hotspots were to be closed in a bid to keep people safe.It led to an estimated , holiday home owners, mostly elderly pensioners, fearing they had less than  hours to collect their belongings and leave – with nowhere  to go.One -year-old woman at a park in Essex, who has lived there for eight years, was left “in tatters and tears” after mistakenly being told to go by park bosses.Another family at a park in Dorset, staying in a holiday home for six months while their house was being renovated, were also told to leave before pm last night.But after almost  hours of confusion, fretting holiday home owners were finally told they were exempt from the evictionthey had nowhere  to go.Government guidance issued by the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said: “Where people live permanently in caravan parks or are staying in caravan parks as interim abodes where their primary residence is not available, they may continue to do so.”The National Caravan Council, which represents motorhome, caravan and holiday home industries, last night insisted people were not obliged to leave their propertiesthey had no alternative accommodation.A spokesman said: “The government’s position,these people do not have access to a permanent residence in the UK, is they should be allowed to stay on park sites.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.“The NCC is issuing guidance to all its park members which reflects this position.”There are some , holiday parks and caravan sites across the UK.The British Holiday  Home Parks Association is urging its , members to close to tourists with immediate effect.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: south englang running out water
story: A report reckons water firms will need four billion litres a day extra to combat climate change.They also need to cut the amount of river, lake and groundwater used by one billion litres a day.Britain’s water supply is set to drop seven per cent by , says the National Audit Office.According to the NAO, three billion litres a day is also lost through leaks.Comptroller Gareth Davies said: “The Government has made limited progress on reducing water consumption, tackling leakage and sharing water resources between regions in the last five years, but rapid progress is now vital for the Government to deliver its objective of a resilient water supply.The Department for Food, Environment and Rural Affairsneeds to provide stronger leadership to water companies, regulators and consumers.The report states that water companies over the past five years have made little or no progress in reducing water consumption and cutting leakage.The NAO has urged the Government to monitor progress on the water suppliers pledge to reduce leakage by at least % by .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian earthquake tsunami
story: Video shows how furniture was seen shaking in offices and apartments as locals scrambled to leave buildings and shopping malls on Russia’s Pacic coastline.People as far as  miles away from Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky could feel light vibrations when the earthquake happened at .am local time.There was also panic in the Kuril Islands - north of Japan - and on the Kamchatka volcano and glacier peninsula.Residents in the northern Kuril Islands remained under threat from a tsunami and were ordered to remain on higher ground then await instructions.A tsunami warning issued by the US authorities for Hawaii was rescinded, and officials said there was no danger to either the US or Canadian west coasts.One video showed the scary impact in an apartment on Paramushir, one of the Kuril Islands.A local said: It was terrying.Another added: Boats were jumping.One said: F***, it was shaking for so long and that was frightening.Reports said a tsunami wave round -feet high was witnessed at Severo-Kurilsk in the Kurils.Electricity and internet was disrupted in Severo-Kurils, kbut there were no reports of fatalities.The Japan Meteorological Association said there might be slight tidal changes but no warnings or watch advisories were issued.A resident of Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, a city of , and some  miles from the undersea epicentre, said: It was shaking for a while. At first not very strong, for a while, then a strong wave. Everyone ran out of their offices.”The area - like the Kurils - is in the earthquake zone but residents were shocked at the severity.Another said: “We were on the fth floor. The swinging went on for a long time, then the cupboards hit against the walls and the doors rattled.“I am used to earthquakes here, but I was scared at the last strong shocks. My grandson aged six was very scared.“Now he doesnt go a step away from me at home. Yes, and the roar was very strong.”A resident of another town posted: “Thank God we stocked on toilet rolls because we really s*** ourselves. Water was pouring everywhere.”For the latest news on this story keep checking back at Sun Online, where we will bring you live updates as soon as they happen, before anyone .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook thesun, and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSun, where we will bring you this story and all the rest of the top news and exclusives of the day.TheSun is your go to destination for the best celebrity news, football news, real-le stories, jaw-dropping pictures and must-see videoOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus infected half population spreading january
story: Coronavirus could already have infected HALF the British population and has been spreading in the UK since January, a new study claims.Oxford University researchers say the deadly bug was circulating around two weeks before the first reported case and a month before the first reported death.This means it could have had enough time to have spread widely - with many iniduals developing immunity.It comes as . million antibody tests have been bought by the government, which will allow people to see whether they have had the virus and are immune to it so they can then get back to work.Sunetra Gupta, a professor of theoretical epidemiology who led the study, said testing was needed to assess the new theory.She said: We need immediately to begin large-scale serological surveys – antibody testing – to assess what stage of the epidemic we are in now.The study from Oxford’s Evolutionary Ecology of Infectious Disease group suggests that Covid- reached the UK by mid-January at the latest.Tap to see where Covid- is near youLike many emerging infections, it spread invisibly for more than a month before the first transmissions within the UK were officially recorded at the end of February.The Oxford study is based on a what is known as a “susceptibility-infected-recovered model” of Covid-, built up from case and death reports from the UK and Italy.The researchers say they made what they believe are the most plausible assumptions about the behaviour of the virus.The modelling brings back into focus “herd immunity” - the idea that the virus will stop spreading when enough people have become resistant to it because they have already been infected.The government abandoned its unofficial herd immunity strategy — allowing controlled spread of infection — after its scientic advisers said this would put the NHS under immense strain with critically ill patients.Despite this, the Oxford results would mean the country had already gained substantial herd immunity through the unrecognised spread of Covid- over more than two months.If the findings are confirmed by testing, then the current restrictions could be removed much sooner than ministers have indicated.To provide the necessary evidence, the Oxford group is working with colleagues at the Universities of Cambridge and Kent to start antibody testing on the general population as soon as possible.Just yesterday, the Health Secretary announced that . million antibody tests had been bought - which will showyou have had Covid-.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Speaking at Downing Street tonight, he said: Weve now bought . million antibody tests that will allow people to see whether they have had the virus and are immune to it and then can get back to work.We expect people not to be able to catch it, except in very exceptional circumstances, for a second time.He added that a new testing facility in Milton Keynes had opened today to process the checks ahead of them being ramped up.The UK yesterday saw its biggest daily spike in deaths from coronavirus with , taking the nationwide total to .Eighty-three of the coronavirus fatalities confirmed on Tuesday were in England, with two in Scotland, one in Wales, and three in Northern Ireland.On top of this , more patients caught the virus - taking the total number of infected Brits over ,.However, the true size of the outbreak is being hidden because of the Governments controversial decision to only test patients in hospital.Former Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt even warned that one million Brits will have caught deadly coronavirus by next week - but we wont know who.He told MPs that scientic modelling has shown that the expected death rate was one fatality for every , cases.Based on the most recent mortality figures, that means more than , people have already contracted the virus in Britain.Andthat number doubles every five days - as experts suggest - there could be more than one million cases by the end of next week, he said.He is now urging for testing to be stepped up dramaticallywe are to get the coronavirus outbreak under control.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: six month mot holiday cars vans motorbikes
story: As The Sun revealed last night, people whose MOT runs out will not have to get a new one from March  onwards.If yours is running out in the next week and you have to use it for work, you still MUST get it done.But after March , you dont need to do so.If you can’t get an MoT that’s due because you’re in self-isolation, the Department for Transport is working with insurers and the police to ensure people aren’t unfairly penalised for things out of their control.Vehicles must be kept in a roadworthy condition, and garages will remain open for any essential repair work.Drivers can still be prosecuteddriving unsafe vehicles.And the Government stressed that no one should be leaving their house unless they absolutely have to.It is only allowed to get vital supplies, exercise once a day, work, or attend a medical appointment.Anything  should only be done unless vital.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said today: “We must ensure those on the frontline of helping the nation combat COVID are able to do so.“Allowing this temporary exemption from vehicle testing will enable vital services such as deliveries to continue, frontline workers to get to work, and people get essential food and medicine.“Safety is key, which is why garages will remain open for essential repair work.”This measure could be extendedthe shutdown is extended.Driving tests were also ditched for the next three months too, the Government announced today. Last week week MOTs in Northern Ireland were suspended for three months by the Driver  Vehicle Agency NI over the Covid- spread.Key workers will still be able to get an MOT on their car during the lockdown.Mechanics have been granted key worker status, while garages will remain open during the coronavirus shutdown, to enable people to keep going to work safely.Cabinet Minister Michael Gove said: “Garages can remain open. And that’s both for essential maintenance of cars to make them safe on the road, and providing petrol.”Garages were specically excluded from those businesses that had to close, but you should check with your local mechanic about what their opening hours are.The DVSA has suspended testing of all heavy goods vehicles , trailers and public service vehiclesfor up to three months and said it is keeping testing of other vehicles under review.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry final goodbye chelsy davy
story: The Duke, , was alone in London after Meghan, , ed to Canada immediately after their final appearance together at the Commonwealth Day ceremony two weeks ago.Lawyer Chelsy, , dated Harry on and off for seven years from  before they finally split .The long-time girlfriend and Harry stayed in touch but decided to end any contact after he married Meghan, , in May .Harry met up with Chelsy after friends arranged a leaving bash while Meghan was back in Canada with Archie.A friend said: Harry knew it would be impossible to see all his pals inidually, so a few of them decided to organise a gathering before he ed to Canada.Harry was beaming when he walked into the room and everyone was there waiting for him. He couldn’t believe his eyes when he saw Chelsy.He gave her the biggest hug. He was thrilled she was there. She and Harry have a serious connection, but I doubt they would ever hook up on anything.Some joked that he didn’t want Meghan tracking him down on GPS.Spending time with people he cares about dearly reminded Harry of the good old days, when he didn’t have a care in the world.He’s gotten in trouble with her before for drinking too much and staying out late, Nothing happened between Harry and Chelsy and deep down Meghan trusts him, the pal told New Idea magazine in Australia.Royal experts claimed Harry wanted to marry Chelsy but she did not enjoy living in the limelight.Meghan is believed to have left London immediately after appearing with Harry at the Commonwealth Day ceremony at Westminster Abbey on Monday March  Harry stayed in London for a few extra days before joining his family in Canada.A spokesman for Meghan and Harry has been approached for comment. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA blame game has erupted over what work should and shouldnapost continue during the coronavirus shutdown, as pictures emerged of packed commuter trains this morning. Concerned workers have complained that they are being told to still come into work despite government advice being to work from home where posssible. Some trains on Londonaposs Tube network were crowded again on Tuesday morning despite Boris Johnson placing the UK on a police-enforced lockdown with drastic new measures in the fight against the coronavirus outbreak. The Prime Minister ordered people only to leave their homes under a list of very limited purposes, banned public gatherings of more than two people and ordered the closure of non-essential shops. But police chiefs warned of phone lines being inundated with calls on Monday night with questions about what movements are still permitted, while MPs also called for answers. And the construction industry has been singled out - with people ided onmuch of the work which is happening at the moment is truly essential. In Downing Staposs daily briefing Matt Hancock said: Of courseyou’re in a workplace we’ve said will close we’re going to enforce against those closures as well. But he did not say whether workers whose workplaces are not shut down can refuse to come in,theyaposre not personally ill. And he defended the governmentaposs policy. Matt Hancock said: “The judgement we have made is in work, in many many instances, the  metre rule can be applied. In my workplace in the House of Commons you can see it every day “Where possible people should work from home”. But he added “employers have a duty to ensure people are more than  metres apart.” Mr Hancock appeared to try and sht the blame for images on full tubes to Transport for London - who have cut tube numbers in the last few day. He said there should be more London Underground trains running.  He said: When it comes to the tube, the first and the best answer is that Transport for London should have the tube running in full so that people travelling on the tube are spaced out and can be further apart - obeying the two-metre rule wherever possible. And there is no good reason in the information that Iaposve seen that the current levels of tube provision should be as low as they are. We should have more tube trains running. But a spokesman for the mayor of London hit back. They said: This is simply not true. The mayor has told ministers countless times over recent days that TfL simply cannot safely run a full service because of the levels of staff sickness and self-isolation. Nearly a third of staff are already absent - there aren’t enough drivers and control staff to do it. The government must act urgently to get more people staying at home rather than going to work unnecessarily - that means taking the dficult decisions they are refusing to take to ban non-essential construction work and provide proper financial support to freelancers, the self employed and those on zero hours contracts to stay at home. The government says people should not go into work in person unless it is absolutely necessary. But unless a firm has been forcibly shut down, the definition of “necessary” is being left up to employers to work out. In these firms, bosses are free to continue asking you to come to work. However, new rules were due to be issued on Tuesday to cover firms whose workers are still going in despite the lockdown.  Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the rules would include a requirement on employers to keep workers  metres from each other. There will be unlimited fines for non compliance though they start at £, he said. Construction firms should also use “common sense” to ensure that distance is maintained, the government said. For instance large-scale construction sites have been told to go ahead - but domestic home extensions should be put on hold.
