title: coronavirus-enjoyleisure-close-county-sports-facilities
story: In a statement yesterdayevening , BillAxon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: "To slow the spread of Covid-,the general public are being advised to stay at home as much as possible and avoid unnecessary social contact."The health and safety of our visitors and staff is our number one priority."We have taken the extremely dficult decision to close our facilities to the public temporarily and will continually monitor the advice from government so that we are in a good position to re-open as quickly as possible when appropriate."We would like to take this opportunity to thank our customers for their continued loyalty and support, and give special mention to our team of incredible colleagues and their continued dedication and commitment to the delivery of enjoyleisure services.From close of business on Friday,enjoyleisure will closeits sports centres and swimming pools, pitches andpavilions, MeadowmillAthletics Arena andits climbing wall at Tranent.Enjoyleisure-managed golf coursesMusselburgh Old Linksand Winterfield, Dunbar, will remain open to the public for now.All fitness and swimming lesson membership customers will have their monthly direct debit payments reduced to poundper month to cover bank and administration costs.Whileall childrenrsquos and adultscoached activity programmes -including gymnastics, trampolining, climbing, and swimming lessons - will cease tomorrow.All upcoming events, hosted by enjoyleisure or other external organisations at enjoyleisure facilities,have been cancelled or postponed.

title: coronavirus-scottish-seabird-centre-closed
story: The closure came into effect yesterdayand it is not known how long it will last.In a statement, Susan Davies, chief executive of the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoIn view of the latest Scottish Government and Public Health Scotland advice, it is with regret that we have to advise our members and visitors that the Scottish Seabird Centre is closing its doors for the time-being."The safety and wellbeing of our staff, volunteers and visitors is of paramount importance to us at this time.ldquoWe are immensely grateful for all the kind words and offers of support we have received since reopening our newly refreshed Discovery Experience and Learning Hub last year.ldquoMany visitors who have dropped in over the last few days have also told us just how much they also enjoy coming into the centre to socialise. We are sorry that we cannot continue to offer our services just now.ldquoYour continued support has meant a lot to our dedicated frontline staff team, at this uncertain time, and importantly has helped support the conservation and education work that charity delivers.ldquoDuring the closure of our visitor centre, our dedicated team will continue to work behind the scenes on project resources, new interactives and to offer new digital resources for members and participants in our activities and events.ldquoWe will keep you up to date with these as they become available via our social media channels. We are also exploring options for appropriate outdoor activities and flexible use of our cafeacute and gt shop whilst closed.ldquoIf you have any queries please do get in touch via info@seabird.org or by calling the office   and leaving a voice message. One of the team will get back to you, although it may take a little longer than usual.ldquoWe will continue to closely monitor the official advice and will keep you updated on our position through our social media channels and website.ldquoWe hope to be able to welcome you back in the near future. In the meantime please stay safe and well.Some of the countyrsquos other big attractions, including several museums and historic castles, announced their closures earlier this week.

title: coronavirus-schools-across-east-lothian-now-closed
story: East LothianCouncil says it is opening a number of childrenrsquos hubs in each of its school cluster areas for youngsters whose parents are identied as key workers or who are vulnerable.The local authority intends to use digital technology to continue lessons for youngsters who were sent home with packs of school work, including books and usernames and passwords to access Google classrooms.A youth football club is also opening its clubhouse for young people who cannot access the internet to connect free for homework.Preston Athletic YFC, based in Prestonpans, have invited children along between pm and pm during the week, with food and drink also being supplied to the youngsters.The club said: ldquoAs of Monday, March , we will open the clubhouse Monday to Friday,  pm. We welcome children who do not have internet access at home to come along and use our internet free off charge to do homework they must bring their own tablet or laptop.ldquoWe will give all children a free juice and biscuit, adults can have a free hot drink. Children can also havea kick about on the Gthey wish.One of the clubrsquos coaches has offered to produce soup and sandwiches for children who attend and Sugar Rush Creations has offered to provide all youngsters who are doing homework in the clubhouse with free popcorn.Meanwhile, East Lothian Council has announced it will have childrenrsquos hubs at the following schools: Dunbar Primary School St Maryrsquos Primary School Haddington Primary School Law Primary School, North BerwickPreston Tower Primary School , PrestonpansSandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, Tranentand Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh.The hubs are expected to be available to children who have at least one parent identied as a key worker and no other adult at home, and will also oversee the distribution of free school meals to eligible children and continue providing support for learning to children with additional support needs.The councilrsquos chief operating officer for education Lesley Brown said:ldquoThis is an extremely challenging time for our school communities, including parents, carers, children and staff. Irsquod like to thank everyone for the support you have given our teams in recent days.ldquoClearly the unprecedented decision to close all schools in Scotland by close of play todaypresents major logistical dficulties and inconvenience for families. Wersquore grateful to everyone for your patience and understanding as we respond to this situation.ldquoWe have continued to work on arrangements which we intend to implement in the coming week. More details will be made available as soon as practically possible.ldquoThanks to our teachers, supported by other staff, we are carrying out work to prepare online learning opportunities to maintain teaching as far as possible. Schools are in touch with parents and carers about this.ldquoWe will be working with our private and voluntary nurseries and our out of school care partners to provide a holistic package of support and will be in touch with them very soon.

title: coronavirus-churches-urged-stop-services-prevent-spread-virus
story: A spokesperson for the Church of Scotland said on Tuesday: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentnow advisesthat people should minimise social contact by avoiding crowded areas and large gatherings, including religious congregations, and smaller gatherings.ldquoThe Church of Scotland now asks, in the strongest terms, that all gatherings for worship should cease until further notice.ldquoOther Scottish churches are taking similar actions."This obviously includes Easter services. Some Presbyteries have already instructed this action. This will include, but not be restricted to: housegroups, meetings for youth work, and church cafes.ldquoIt will still be possible for an inidual to offer a livestream of a sermon and prayers.ldquoChurch buildings can be kept open as a place for people to come and pray.Notices should be clearly displayedasking that visitors observe robust hand hygiene, including washing their hands on entry to the church.On weddings and funerals, the Church said that ldquosensitive conversations will need to take place between those affected.The Rev Alison McDonald, from St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington, sent a message to her congregation after the Church of Scotland called for services to be cancelled.She said weekly readings, prayers and reflections would be posted online and plans are being consideredto open the church building for ldquopersonal prayer as the coronavirus crisis continues.The Scottish Episcopal Churchhas also asked its clergy to cease church services.The Most Rev Dr Mark Strange, Primus of the SEC, said: ldquoThis is a dficult time for many people some are fearful for themselves or their relatives, while others want to know how to help stem the spread of the virus.ldquoOur guidance is given not just to address medical concerns but also with pastoral concern being uppermost in our hearts and minds, particularly the care of the vulnerable in our congregations and communities.Church buildings will be allowed to stay open for private prayer. The church will also deliver a video service of the Eucharist every Sunday through its website for those wanting to worship at home.The Catholic Church has cancelled public Masses across Scotland from Thursday and they will not take place until further notice.Masses will still be said in private in churches but not in front of parishioners live streaming will be in place and available where possible.Catholic churches themselves will not be closed completely to allow time for private prayer.

title: weightlifting-headteacher-earns-podium-position-international-event
story: Lynda Banks represented Great Britain at the European Masters Classic Powerlting Championships in France last Monday .The Cockenzie Primary School headteacher lted a whopping  kilogrammes across the three events in the age -,  kilogrammes category, to come home with two bronze medals from the competition in Albi, near Toulouse.Ms Banksrsquo powerlting prowess came about ldquoby pure chance.She had started training at a gym in Inverness when she was , with a view to being strong enough to complete a chin-up.That was successfully achieved and a love of deadlting followed, with the -year-oldrsquos first competition in Dumfries in .Within  months, she had a gold medal for deadlts as part of the British team.Ms Banks swapped Hilton Primary School in Inverness for East Lothian in October last year, the new head replacing Jacqui MacKinnon, who moved on to North Berwickrsquos Law Primary School.The headteacherrsquos positive mental attitude influences her approach to school title: tims-tales-monkey-delivery
story: ldquoWRITE something uplting or funny, my we Kate told me this morning. Shersquos right, of course. We need such stories just now.My response was: ldquoYes, we all need to make our own version of Stone Soup.My youngest daughter overheard me. ldquoYuck, I donrsquot want that, I want porridge for breakfast like usual, she said.I reassured her and reminded her of the story. Itrsquos an old tale Irsquove shared in these pages before. It has many versions and I base the story in a land when there is a famine and people have very little food on which to survive, and so understandably people keep what little they have for their own use.But then a wise traveller fills his pot with water and begins to boil it over a fire. Then he adds a stone. People get curious and ask: ldquoWhat are you making  The traveller replies: ldquoStone soup.ldquoStone soup  Never heard of that.ldquoOh, itrsquos delicious and very filling.ldquoCould I try some ldquoOf course, but it would taste betteryou had something to add to it, says the traveller.And so as the story unfolds, each person adds a little to the pot, which means in the end the soup really is delicious and filling, and there is enough for all, because everyone has shared the little they have.But before they eat, the traveller does one last thing ndash takes out the stone!My daughter remembered the story and was reassured stone soup wasnrsquot on the breakfast menu. But I think the storyrsquos meaning has deeper signicance than just the sharing of food. Itrsquos also about the sharing of ourselves, and how adding a little bit of who we are can transform the pot of community.In the midst of all the fear and panic around us just now, this is what is happening. People are helping out, checking on neighbours and thinking how their own behaviour can affect others who are more vulnerable.And in all this, our mental wellbeing is as important as our physical health. Irsquom reminded of something my motherrsquos partner once told me. His name was Harry. He was originally from Holland and in his childhood he lived through the horric Dutch famine of -.He said: ldquoWe survived on rotten potato soup, tulip bulbs and a joke a day. Sometimes the jokes were as rotten as the potatoes but just as important!We need to smile, laugh and feel connected, especially in dficult times. We can all begin our own metaphorical stone soup and invite others to contribute and share.For example, many of my fellow storytellers are arranging online storytelling sessions. I will be telling stories online for the schools I currently work with and Irsquom happy to do likewise for any other organisation or group ndash once my six-year-old has taught me how the technology works!There are local musicians playing online gigs, people sharing recipes, visiting older family members outside their windows, writing letters and telephoning people for a chat the list goes on. One idea can lead to another, and soon a new community pot is made!Every contribution, no matter how seemingly small, can make a big dference to that pot. And in so doing, it will challenge that sense of despair and powerlessness that so many of us feel right now.So the question should be: Whatrsquos your thing  How can you safely share it  Whatrsquos your amusing or uplting story or your talent  Think about it and letrsquos share, for others, as well as ourselves.And so in the spirit of this, here is my wee contribution for this week itrsquos a funny wee tale passed onto me, so I claim no credit or originality for it. It was told to me by an Irish friend, but Irsquove adapted it slightly.There was this van driver called George who got a job delivering monkeys to the zoo. Unfortunately, his van broke down and while waiting for the mechanic the monkeys began to get restless.Then another van driver called Archie pulled up and askedhe could help.ldquoIrsquom late for my delivery. If I give you pound, will you take these monkeys to the zoo  asked George.ldquoSure, said Archie.So Archie took the monkeys away in his van.George waited for the mechanic and finally his van was repaired. He then set off for the zoo to make sure the monkeys were delivered successfully.But to his surprise, he saw Archie walking along the street with the monkeys!George called out to him: ldquoWhat are you doing  I gave you pound to take the monkeys to the zoo!Archie called back: ldquoI did, but we got a group discount, I have some money left, so now Irsquom taking them to the cinema!

title: coronavirus-residents-urged-keep-helping-east-lothian-foodbank
story: The foodbank, based in Tranent, provides food parcels to vulnerable members of the community.Candace Higgins, foodbank director, said the situation was changing ldquohour by hour, adding: ldquoWe are still operating as normal but certain protocols have been put in place when delivering food parcels.Volunteers making deliveries are now simply knocking on doors or ringing bells, rather than waiting for doors to be opened to them. The parcels can then be left in safe places, while, at the charityrsquos headquarters on Civic Square, ldquostringent cleanliness and health and safety rules are in place.Candace praised the local community for their continued support in making donations to the group.She said: ldquoWe are really benefiting from having such a fantastic community. Donations have gone up rather than down.However, she also issued a call for people to stop panic or bulk buying.She added: ldquoWe are running low on chopped tomatoes, long-le fruit juice, instant mash potato and tinned potatoes. In terms of household items, it would be the same things as everyone  is running low on ndash kitchen roll, toilet roll and baby wipes.The foodbank is staffed by volunteers and Candace said they anticipated a number of volunteers who are over the age of  would have to remain in their homes over the coming weeks, with a reduced schedule of deliveries. Instead, moves could be made to change the model to a pantry and larder model.The foodbank was visited at the end of last week by the countyrsquos MP, Kenny MacAskill, who met with  volunteers.He said: ldquoThe foodbank is a treasure, but the circumstances that have made these projects so important are the result of bad choices by successive Governments.ldquoItrsquos especially important now with the coronavirus pandemic that we continue to support our local foodbank to make sure those in crisis are able to have at least the comfort of a hot meal.

title: explained-difference-self-isolating-social-distancing
story: As spring begins the days are getting longer and warmer, and people are getting the urge to venture outside of their homes after winter.But amid the spread of coronavirus, many people are not sure whether it is safe for them to get out in the open air, or whether they have to stay inside.Here is the dference between social distancing, and social isolating - and what it means for you.Who needs to self isolate The governmentrsquos advice is that anyone who is experiencing symptoms of coronavirus - a dry cough, fever, or dficulty breathing - must self-isolate for a two week period.Anyone classied as lsquovulnerablersquo also has to self-isolate. This includes people over , as well as people with underlying conditions that could make the symptoms of coronavirus worse.Unfortunately for these people, self-isolation means not leaving your house - making going walks outside or meeting friends an impossibility. But the government does say people who are self-isolating can keep windows open to get fresh air.Whatrsquos social distancing The government is advising everyone who is not currently self-isolating to still practise social distancing.This means not meeting with friends and family, staying away from crowded areas, avoiding all non-essential travel, and working from home where possible.Luckily for these people, there is no restriction on going for walks outside. The government website actually encourages people to get plenty of exercise and fresh air.ldquoAt times like these, the website reads, ldquoit can be easy to fall into unhealthy patterns of behaviour which in turn can make you feel worse."Its only warning is not to get too close to other people when outside, asking walkers to stay at least two metres away from each other.Coronavirus: the facts by the World Health Organisation and the NHSWhat is coronavirus COVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.What caused coronavirus The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.How is it spread As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.What are the symptoms The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.What precautions can be taken Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.Government adviceAs of Monday, March , the government advised that everyone should be observing social distancing - avoiding unnecessary travel and working from home where possible. Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms now needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The over s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate.For more information on government advice, please check their website.Should I avoid public places The advice now is to avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.What should I doI feel unwell Donrsquot go to your GP but instead call NHS  or look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.When to call NHS NHS  should be usedyou feel unwell with coronavirus symptoms, have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus.

title: tesco-take-20-000-new-staff
story: Tesco has become the latest supermarket to announce plans to recruit new staff to cope with the coronavirus outbreak overwhelming stores.The UKrsquos biggest grocer said it will recruit , temporary workers for at least the next  weeks.Its recruitment drive was launched on Wednesday, adding ldquosince then we have already been overwhelmed by support from the public and thank everyone who has applied to work with us in stores.Some staff are being interviewed, processed and working within the same day, Tesco added.Tescorsquos HR chief, Natasha Adams, said: ldquoIrsquom so proud to be welcoming thousands of new colleagues to Tesco. title: coronavirus-dunbar-civic-week-postponed
story: Dunbarrsquos Civic Week was due to take place from June  to  but the townrsquos community councillors have taken the tough decision to cancel the annual celebration amid fears surrounding coronavirus.George Robertson, chairman of the Civic Week planning committee, spoke to the Courier on Thursday, with the decision officially taken to cancel the event just days later.He said: ldquoThere are discussions taking place and it is very likely to be cancelled.ldquoThat is my recommendation to the community council and I am awaiting them to come back to me.Traditionally, Civic Week, which started in , features dozens of events, ranging from football tournaments to a cycle ride.The townrsquos leboat station opens its doors to visitors and live music is performed at The Battery, at the townrsquos harbour.Central to the event is the crowning of Dunbarrsquos Civic Week Queen, who is a randomly chosen female P pupil from the town.Mr Robertson said there were concerns that coronavirus would decimate the programme, which is already in the process of being drawn up.He said: ldquoYou cannot have a fun day or a parade with  people.ldquoA lot of people are going to be in lockdown.ldquoIt is a real blow and it could not have come at a worse time [the event was due to celebrate  years] but in the grand scheme of things, cancelling Dunbar Civic Week, like Wimbledon and Glastonbury, does not amount to a whole lot of grievance.ldquoI was quite anxious we made a decision.ldquoWe were discussing this before the school closure came about and we were due to have a draw on March  for the Royal Court.Mr Robertson, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said ldquoa lot of preparation had already gone into the event and thanked the work of volunteers Eileen Moore and Sanchita Patjoshi in pulling everything together.It remains to be seenthe event will be rescheduled for later in the year or simply resume in the summer of .Mr Robertson noted that attempting to hold the event later in the year created a number of other potential issues.No one knows when everyday events couldto normal in the wake of COVID-, while the children who are currently in P would have moved on to Dunbar Grammar School by the time the event could be held.This yearrsquos event was also due to mark the th anniversary of the granting of the Royal Charter to Dunbar.The Royal Charter was granted to Dunbar by King David the Secondin .This came about because Berwick-upon-Tweed was then in English hands and the lucrative revenues from the export of border wool was lost to the Scottish crown.The granting of a Royal Charter to Dunbar meant that this trade could now go via Dunbar and the port of Belhaven, and revenues revert to Scotland.The th anniversary was celebrated in grand style in  with the very first Dunbar Civic Week, and Civic Week has continued annually ever since.

title: coronavirus-scotland-essentially-already-lockdown-businesses-told-close
story: Nicola Sturgeon also indicated that Scotland is essentiallyalready in ldquolockdown, but without it being enforced.She warned that people should remain at home ldquounless itrsquos absolutely essential to go out ndash while Scotlandrsquos chief medical officer, Catherine Calderwood, said that people can go out and exercise once a day but ldquoonly in small family groups.Ms Sturgeon said that the advice issued is ldquorules that we are expecting people to comply with and that businesses that cannot operate remotely should ldquoconsider closing or hibernating.She added: ldquoFor everyone, you must stay at home unless it is absolutely essential to go out. That includes working from home wherever possible.ldquoStay away from crowded places, even out of doors. When there are other people around, stay two metres distance from them.ldquoThat advice is for everyone but it is especially vitalyou are over , eligible for the flu vaccine or pregnant. At all times, follow the advice on washing your hands, using tissues and touching your face.Ms Sturgeon pleaded with businesses that have not yet closed their doors to the public.She said: ldquoIf you are not providing essential items like food and medicines, then please also close now.ldquoThere are still too many people across our country who are being expected to or are expecting to go to work as normal. That presents a serious and unnecessary risk of spreading the virus.Ms Sturgeon added that building sites and hair salons should also close to help in the efforts to suppress the coronavirus pandemic.She added: ldquoI know this is a dficult situation for businesses and I know dficult judgements are having to be made.ldquoI have therefore asked for additional guidance to be drawn up urgently by government for businesses that will make clear exactly what we are expecting of them and how they can make theright judgements on what is essential and whatis not essential.ldquoWe are pushing for and are very hopeful of seeing very seen, further measures to support freelancers, the self-employed and contract workers.ldquoIt should enable businesses to do the right thing for themselves and for their workers.Dr Calderwood said that it was important that people couldleeavetheir homes to exercise once a day for mental and physical wellbeing, but urged people to do it in small family groups to stop the spread of coronavirus.She said: ldquoPeople should go out once a day to exercise but donrsquot do it except in small family groups.ldquoWe are going to have to adapt to le in this new world. We are really in this for the marathon, not a sprint.The First Minister also indicated that Scotland and wider UK is essentially already in ldquolockdown as has been described in Italy and other countries ndash albeit without the enforcement.She said: ldquoIt is very possible that in the days to come, we will see more stringent measures be applied.ldquoIf we take a step back from the word lsquolockdownrsquo, and think about what all the components of that would be - asking people to stay at home and not go to work unless it isvitally essential, asking people not to go shopping unless itrsquos for food and medicine, asking people to keep their distance, not gather in crowds of people.ldquoThatrsquos essentially the elements of what you are seeing in other countries where it has been described as lockdown."I guess the missing bit that we may have to move tothe advice tells us itrsquos necessary, iswhether that is beingissued in a way of advice, although Irsquom being very clear we want people to treat it as rules, or whether there is more enforcement on that. I canrsquot rule that out.She added: ldquoAs First Minister, I will not hesitate to do what is necessary here. Irsquom not ruling anything out.ldquoWhat Irsquom being crystal clear on is that the public donrsquot have to wait for lockdowns or enforcement to do the right things.ldquoItrsquos within the ability of each and every one of us as citizens to do the right things now. Donrsquot wait for somebody to tell you - please do it.

title: wetherspoons-boss-tells-staff-go-work-tesco-leaving-no-pay
story: After being forced to closehundred of pubs over the weekend to battle the spread of Covid-, Martin sent a video to staff members claiming that he would be relying on a Government grant to pay workers.However, the grant will not be available for well over a monthand Martin,who is reportedly worth over pound million, will not be covering staff wages until then.More than , workers have been left without a future pay date, unsure how they will be able to afford rent, bills or groceries.A letter from members of Wetherspoons staffOther companies, such as Costa Coffee, have guaranteed that staff will be paid for the next eight weeks despite also shutting their doors.The move came shortly after Martin claimed the global pandemic was nothing more than a "health scare" and that the closing pubs would be an "over the top" reaction.In the video sent to staff, in which Martin appears holding a mug, he stated that the need to close "puts everyone in a terrible position"."And I know youre all sitting there wondering what the hell is happening and over the weekend I had lots of phone calls with dferent people and were trying to sort it out as best we can in this highly unusual situation."The Wetherspoons bossthen encourages staff to go work at Tesco.He said: "I know that all our trade now has gone to supermarkets. Not only our trade, but the trade from cafeacutes, leisure centres, restaurants etc."So we have had lots of calls from supermarkets, Tesco alone want , people to join them. Thats half the amount of people who work in our pubs."Martin then says staff member have the option to leave rather than waiting for payments to begin - but theres no guarantee they would get their job back at a future date.He said: "If Im honest, I could say you can get the furlough payments and stay at home."If youre offered a job at a supermarket, many of you will want to do that. If you think its a good idea, do it."I can completely understand it. title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. title: TV REVIEW  Did Glasgow-set drama The Nest get off to a flying start
story: FORGET about the column inches Michelle Mone has racked up, or the seat in the House of Lords. Nothing says you have officially arrived more than a name check in a BBC Sunday night drama.ldquoIrsquom going to be an entrepreneur, says the troubled teenager at the heart of The Nest. ldquoKnow that lassie that invented that bra  Michelle Mone  Now shersquos a baroness or some ****. business card. The Nest is set in Monersquos hometown of Glasgow. While ostensibly a drama about surrogacy, it is really a tale of two cities, two Scotlands, the haves and the have nots.Property developer Dan and his musician we Emily , have everything, including a stunning lochside home, but not the child they long for.Kayahas a flat in Possil with barely a stick of furniture in it, and the kind of temper that sees her threaten to stab her case worker with a bottle.The opposites collide when Emily gets lost one night and hits -year-old Kaya with her car. So far, so Bonfire of the Vanities. The teen starts to work her way into the older womanrsquos le and, long story short, offers to be a surrogate infor pound,.Dan thinks this is a crazy idea, not to mention illegal. As does his sister, his lawyer, Emilyrsquos colleague, and probably every viewer watching. Many a drama would struggle to get beyond such a point, but the writer here is Nicole Taylor , who carefully takes each objection and picks away at it.: Susan Swarbrick meets Martin CompstonUltimately, the viewer has to believe that Emily is unhinged by grief, and that Dan would give in because he is desperate to keep her. Madness happens when people convince themselves a situation is all or nothing, black or white. That is how noir works.Even so, Taylorrsquos story is such a high-wire act that it needs to keep propelling itself onwards at speed or it will crash to the ground in a heap of improbabilities.Helping immensely with the task of keeping the viewer on side is a terric cast. Rundle is a convincing mix of fierce determination and eggshell fragility. Mack, a real find, does that bravest of things as an actor and makes herself an unlikeable pain in the neck.Then there is Compston. Once the prince of Sunday nights as Essex wide boy DS Arnott in Line of Duty, he is even better back on his home turf and in his own accent.It was a nice touch by Taylor to make Dan a bad boy made good, eventhe working class middle class contrast was laid on a a bit thick. Every time Kaya appeared the score would slip into menacing music mode, as though people who do not live in beautul lochside homes were naturally best avoided.What a house, mind. As in Guilt, Glasgow scrubbed up well. While The Nestrsquos location choices were more obvious ndash the Botanic Gardens, City Chambers, Kelvingrove Park ndash so far there is not a red sandstone tenement in sight.With four episodes to go, Taylorrsquos cleverly sleekit drama is shaping up nicely, playing on viewersrsquo assumptions.
